4.checklist_item: Application agents configured per application and reporting data
4.tooltip: Number of app server agents deployed per application
4.high_level_exit_criteria: Deploy at least 1 app server agent per application

1.remediation_item: At least one agent per application must be reporting data. If agent is installed and not reporting any data, please validate your installation.

2.remediation_item: If an application is no longer being monitored, ensure the agent is uninstalled and the application is removed from the Controller. Uninstalling an agent will also ensure that the license is returned to the pool.

1.remediation_item: Most applications have more than one agent attached to their process/vms. Currently you have <eval>count(numberOfAgentsReportingData > 1)</eval> applications with more than one agent reporting data.

2.remediation_item: Be mindful of your Machine Agent installs. Typically each node has a machine agent running on it that collect node specific metrics for correlation. Currently there are <eval>count(numberNodesWithMachineAgentInstalled != 0)</eval> applications showing machine agents installed.

1.high_level_exit_criteria: At least 1 business transaction rule configured per application using a custom match rules
1.exit_criteria_logic: Number of Business Transactions discovered using custom match rule >= 1
1.min_pass_threshold: Number of Business Transactions discovered using customer match rule >= 1

1.remediation_item: Consult online documentation on how to configure Custom Match Rules on a per application basis.

2.remediation_item: Make sure the application is having load on all the relevant functions. And follow other Best Practices to create Business Transactions.

3.remediation_item: If no Business Transaction gets discovered check if the technologies used is available in Supported Environments e.g. for the Java Agent: Java Supported Environments.

4.remediation_item: Live Preview can be a helpful tool to create Custom Match rules if nothing gets discovered.

1.remediation_item: Ensure the BT Lockdown flag is enabled. This flag ensures that newly discovered BT's are only added to the All Other transactions logical bucket. Currently <eval>count(btLockdownEnabled == False)</eval> of your applications have this flag disabled.

2.remediation_item: See this video on why and how of locking down your Business Transactions.

2.tooltip: Number of business transactions discovered per application (through either Auto Discovery or Custom match rules)
2.high_level_exit_criteria: Add at least 5 Business Transactions per application

1.remediation_item: Ensure each monitored application has at least 5 business transactions in Business Transactions showing under Business Transactions tab.

2.remediation_item: Consult online documentation on how to configure Business Transactions on a per application basis.

1.remediation_item: Adding custom BT detection rules can further surface important business critical transactions that might not normally be captured using auto discovery.  Currently there are <eval>count(numberCustomMatchRules > 0)</eval> applications with more than 1 custom BT detection rule. Consider adding a custom rule to every application.

2.remediation_item: Too many BT's discovered, whether through auto discovery or a misconfigured custom rule, can wreak havoc on your instrumentation and you can potentially miss out on important BTs. The rule is that less is more. Currently <eval>count(numberOfBTs >= 50)</eval> application(s) have more than 50 BTs. Consider evaluating the need for that many BTs in your applications.

3.tooltip: Number of health rules configured per application
3.high_level_exit_criteria: Create at least 2 Health rules on per application basis
3.exit_criteria_logic: Number of Health Rules >= 2 per application

1.remediation_item: Check out the Health Rules documentation.

2.remediation_item: Make sure you fine-tune Metric evaluation to avoid false positives and alert spams.

1.remediation_item: Tuned Health Rules are important in keep noise at minimum. There are some generic out of box health rules. To further improve your the health rules consider creating at lease one custom health rule per application. Currently there are <eval>count(numberOfCustomHealthRules > 0)</eval> applications with more than one or more custom health rule.

2.remediation_item: Check out on-demand and free webcasts covering all aspects of AppDynamics.

4.checklist_item: Create Data Collectors and Detection Rules
4.tooltip: Number of data collectors and detection rules created across all applications
4.high_level_exit_criteria: Define Data Collectors, Create Data Collection Rules
4.exit_criteria_logic: Number of Data Collectors >= 1 across all applications(i.e. not per application)

1.remediation_item: See online documentation on how to configure Data Collection Rules on a per application basis.

2.remediation_item: Checkout this helpful online community post on how to trouble-shoot using data collectors.

1.remediation_item: Data Collectors can help get to MTTR faster by supplementing your troubleshooting workflow with application level data. Make sure the data fields configured in a collector are properly capturing the desired application data.

2.remediation_item: Currently there are <eval>count(numberOfDataCollectorFieldsConfigured > 0)</eval> have data collectors configured.

3.remediation_item: Misconfigured data collectors will not property collect the data items desired. Currently <eval>count(numberOfDataCollectorFieldsCollectedInSnapshots > 0)</eval> data items have been collected during a snapshot capture over the last few hours

1.remediation_item: Too many Health Rule violations on per application basis can create Alert Fatigue. Currently <eval>count(numberOfHealthRuleViolations > 30)</eval> application(s) show triggering Health rule violations greater than 30 over the last few hours. This might be ok based on your use case but consider revisiting the rules for optimal configuration

2.remediation_item: Policies attach critical HR violations to Actionable Alerts such as notifying developers though Slack, generating service ticket, notifying Ops teams about an issue, etc. This is part of a pro-active monitoring stance. Consider adding actionable Alerts to critical HR violations. Currently only <eval>count(numberOfActionsBoundToEnabledPolicies > 0)</eval> show having Policies that tie HR violations to some sort of Action.
